awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of marine organohalogen bioaccumulation and neurotoxicity
awd_abstract_narration:
There is an urgent public health need to better understand the relative risks and benefits associated with consumption of seafood. This project will investigate how natural and man-made organohalogen compounds, some of which are known to be toxic, accumulate in marine food webs on the way to human consumption. Researchers at UC San Diego Scripps Institution of Oceanography and UC Davis will investigate the biological mechanisms behind the uptake and concentration of these compounds, and also the mechanisms that make them toxic. The project will support two postdoctoral researchers, thus directly contributing to the development of early career scienctists. The research is jointly supported by NSF and by the National Institute for Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS).

The project has two aims. Aim 1 seeks to understand cellular mechanisms that control how toxic marine compounds, specifically organohalogens, bioaccumulate, focusing on xenobiotic transporters as the key pathway. The investigators will determine the interactions of the four major human xenobiotic transporters (XTs) with environmentally relevant natural and man-made marine organohalogens. In parallel, they will take advantage of recent progress with heterologous transporter-expression and CRISPR/CAS9 gene editing in sea urchins, to dissect the functional role of XTs in governing bioaccumulation in marine cells. Aim 2 of the project will determine the structure-activity relationships governing neurotoxicity of marine pollutants. The team will use primary cultures of hippocampal neurons cultured from male and female wild type mice to determine how activity at these molecular targets alter neuronal calcium dynamics and morphology using real-time fluorescence cell imaging and morphometric approaches. In addition, they will determine how hippocampal neurons that express a particular mutation alter sensitivity to organohalogens, and ask whether these effects are gender-specific. These studies will address the critical need to better understand the molecular mechanisms by which naturally occurring and man-made seafood pollutants accumulate in target cells and perturb the calcium dynamics essential for normal neuronal network development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Title: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of marine organohalogen bioaccumulation and neurotoxicity 

The Pessah laboratory has investigated chemically diverse organohalogens found in the marine environment that have both natural and anthropogenic origins to determine whether they target and modify calcium signaling mechanisms that are fundamentally conserved across species and thus regulate a wide range of fundamentally conserved physiological processes, including neurotransmission, muscle contraction and thermoregulation. Chemical classes studied during the 5-year project period include bromopyrroles (BrPyr), brominated bipyrroles (BrBPyr), and brominated diphenyl ethers (PBDE) naturally synthesized in marine environments. We compared their biological effects to man-made PBDE, brominated bisphenols (TBBPA) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) that have industrial origins and have broadly contaminated both aquatic and marine ecosystems. Over the last 5 years, we developed and refined serval bioassays to rapidly determine which chemical structures within each of these chemical classes have potent activities towards two highly conserved, functionally coupled proteins that tightly regulate calcium (Ca2+) concentrations within most vertebrate and invertebrate cell types.  This is important because Ca2+ is among the most important second messengers known and changes in its concentration produce spatially and temporally encoded second messenger information that regulate many, if not most, aspects of development/maturation, metabolism, thermoregulation, neurotransmission and muscle contraction. Our findings are particularly significant to the missions of the NSF Oceans and Human Health program because human activities, such as modern wastewater treatment/disinfection technologies, global contamination with industrial persistent organic pollutants (POPs) and warming temperatures affected by climate change converge on mechanisms that adversely affect the fidelity of Ca2+signaling with deleterious influences on the health of both terrestrial life (including humans) and marine life, including heat stress tolerance. We established and refined in vitro and cellular bioassays that tested the hypothesis that organohalogens, regardless of their origins, produce their biological effects via a highly conserved (convergent) mechanisms that alter the spatial and temporal patterns of Ca2+ transport dynamics within nerve and muscle cells, with a specific focus on their ability to produce heat stress intolerance and neurotoxicity. Prior to and in support of receiving funding from the NSF Oceans and Human Health Program, we accumulated a substantial amount of data demonstrating that anthropogenic nondioxin-like (NDL) PCBs, PBDEs, and triclosan have extremely potent activity towards sensitizing and/or inactivating ryanodine-sensitive Ca2+ channels termed ryanodine receptors (RyRs). Within each of these chemical classes we defined their respective structure-activity relationships (SARs) to identify the most potent/efficacious structures within each class. Collectively, the results they have proved highly significant because they have identified specific chemical structures that are commonly found in human, animal, and environmental samples. These same structures have also been correlated to a plethora of health risks not only in studies with mammals, but also in fish models, wildlife and human epidemiologic studies.  These discoveries provide important mechanistic insights about potential disruptive influences of specific organohalogens on marine ecology and contributions to human health risks. We have disseminated our findings in 12 peer reviewed scientific journals and at national scientific meetings.
